results.title: North and south
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode two of ‘A History of British art’ looks at the brilliant, mad excessiveness of the Elizabethan visual imagination, in architecture, painting, gardening and language. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: Dreams and hammers
results.creator_credit: Paul Tickell, Tanya Seghatchian and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “A History of British art”.
Episode one of ‘A History of British art’ looks at two extraordinary, forgotten legacies at the heart of the British art tradition: the lost tradition of Catholic medieval art, and the tradition of post-Reformation iconoclasm- an entire culture that was devoted to destroying art. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

results.title: Dreamlives [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jennifer Crone and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Partners in life and art, Sydney photographers Narelle Autio and Trent Park discuss why they are drawn to one another’s work and what inspires and motivates them when they are behind the lens. Cameras follow the pair as they photograph goat racing in Lightning Ridge and attempt to capture the essence of Sydney city. They talk of work on their first collaboration in 2001 - the Seventh wave - which depicted images of Australian beach life and garnered them the World Press Award. They also speak of the moniker of “The Roo couple,” coined for their surrealistic images of dead animals by the roadside.

results.title: Dread beat and blood
results.creator_credit: Franco Rosso and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: A unique combination of poetry, music, and politics is portrayed in this film about black reggae musician Lindsay Kwesi Johnson. The lifestyle of blacks in Britain is shown and the pressures they live under. Johnson is seen giving poetry readings in the recording studio as a black activist.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Franco Rosso and Arts Council of Great Britain

results.title: Drawings that walk and talk
results.creator_credit: K H Frank, Marie Seton, British Film Institute and National Film Archive (Great Britain)
results.brief_description: Traces briefly the history of the animated cartoon. Discusses the purpose of caricature giving an animal a man’s mind and behaviour pattern. Includes excerpts from “Drama Among the Puppets” (France 1908), an Otto Herman treatment (Germany pre 1914), and many others from France, England and America. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Drama school
results.creator_credit: Kate Bannatyne, Rachel Landers, Chris Hilton, Michael Cordell, Hilton Cordell Productions, Seven Network Limited (Australia), Trouble and TV 3 New Zealand
results.brief_description: Television documentary series in the ‘reality TV’ genre that follows a year in the life of students at Australia’s best known drama school, the National Institute for Dramatic Art (NIDA) in Sydney. The series begins with the gruelling audition process, then charts the progress of the successful candidates through their first year of the three year course. Simultaneously, the challenges faced by the students who have made it to third year are documented, as they prepare for graduation and entry into the professional world of acting. The series places a strong emphasis on the personal struggles of the students as they face the challenges involved in learning to become professional actors. Contents: Tape 1: Ep. 1 The Auditions—Ep. 2 D-Day—Ep. 3 Boot Camp NIDA—Ep. 4 The Queen—Ep. 5 This Glamorous Life. Tape 2: Ep. 6 Stage Fright—Ep. 7 Agent’s Week—Ep. 8 The Never Ending Audition—Ep. 9 The Final Curtain. Each episode is 30 minutes in duration. Cast includes: NIDA actors: Zoe Houghton, Anthony Radojevic, Romy Bartz, Thom Campbell, Genevive O’Reilly, Socratis Otto, Amie McKenna, Lauren Steenholdt, Daniel Billet. Visiting director: Barrie Kosky. NIDA staff: Tony Knight, Julia Cotton, Kevin Jackson, Bill Pepper, Tim Patston. Music by David Bridie. Narrated by Sacha Horler.

results.title: Dragon lord = Long shaoye
results.creator_credit: Jackie Chan, Leonard Ho and Golden Harvest
results.brief_description: In this, the third in a trilogy of early films that Jackie Chan both directed and starred in, Chan refines his screen persona of the precocious, mischievious kung fu kid. Despite his comic buffoonery, when it comes to the crunch his highly honed martial arts skills save the day. Like the previous films in the trilogy (“The Fearless Hyena” (1979), “The Young Master” (1980)), ‘Dragon Lord’ is set in the countryside during the late Quing period. Chan plays the son of a wealthy man. He and his childhood friend spend their time participating in sporting events and competing to woo the village beauty. His carefree life takes a more serious turn when he stumbles upon a sinister villain who is attempting to smuggle priceless antiquities out of the country. The film features thrilling sporting sequences, a suspenseful rooftop encounter with a group of spear-wielding baddies, a playful acrobatic fight in an art gallery, and a show-stopping twenty minute final brawl that is a classic of Hong Kong action cinema. While not considered one of Chan’s best films, the over-the-top comic action sequences, featuring crazy stunts and rapid editing he pioneered in ‘Dragon Lord’ had a major impact on the subsequent development of Hong Kong action cinema. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: The Simpsons arcade cabinet
results.brief_description: The Simpsons arcade game set itself apart from other brawlers and TV game properties with the show’s main cast voicing the characters, who have unique weapons to swing at enemies. Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t use a three-wood golf club.
results.description:
The Simpsons had only screened one season when Konami released this side-scrolling beat em up in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew how successful The Simpsons would be, it’s that they already had the foundation for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied the same mechanics to The Simpsons, which featured almost identical play style and button mashing combat. What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions, with the TV show’s main cast voicing the characters in the game.

Players can control either Homer, Marge, Bart or Lisa as they use unique fighting techniques – punching or swinging a vacuum cleaner, skateboard or skipping rope – to rescue Maggie after she’s kidnapped by Smithers.

Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t swing a three-wood golf club.
description_for_label:
The Simpsons had only been on-air for one season when Konami released this four-player side-scrolling ‘beat em up’ in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew what a phenomenon The Simpsons would become, it’s that they already had the blueprints for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the successful Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied the same mechanics to The Simpsons, which featured almost identical play style and two-button combat.

What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions of everyone’s favourite Springfield residents, with the TV show’s main cast voicing the characters in the game. Players control either Homer, Marge, Bart or Lisa as they use unique fighting techniques – punching, swinging a vacuum cleaner, skateboard or skipping rope – to rescue Maggie after she’s kidnapped by Smithers. Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t swing a three-wood golf club.

results.title: Dr. Seuss video classics
results.creator_credit: Ray Messecar, Tish Rabe, Greenlight Media and Random House
results.brief_description: Dr. Seuss’s incredible tales and wonderful drawings have delighted children of all ages. The picture books are read by well known actors and feature animation and stills.
